title: Larry Walker (artist)
text:
Larry Walker (born October 22, 1935) is an American visual artist and professor emeritus of art. He often uses mixed media collages that represent "urban surfaces" on the subjects of existentialism and social injustice. Walker currently lives and works in <a href="Stonecrest%2C%20Georgia">Stonecrest, Georgia</a> and has taught at <a href="University%20of%20the%20Pacific%20%28United%20States%29">University of the Pacific</a> and <a href="Georgia%20State%20University">Georgia State University</a>.
Early life.
Walker was born in <a href="Franklin%2C%20Georgia">Franklin, Georgia</a>, on October 22, 1935. In 1941, several years after his father's passing, Walker's family moved to <a href="Harlem">Harlem</a> where he was inspired by the urban life around him. Walker mentions people-watching from his apartment building's sixth story fire escape, experiences taking the train as a southerner in a large city, and his 145th street community as some of the major inspirations behind his work.
Career.
Walker graduated from the High School of Music & Art (now <a href="Fiorello%20H.%20LaGuardia%20High%20School">Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School</a>), and relocated to <a href="Detroit">Detroit</a> to attend <a href="Wayne%20State%20University">Wayne State University</a>, where he received both his B.S. in Art Education and M.A. in Drawing and Painting. In 1964, Walker began teaching at the <a href="University%20of%20the%20Pacific%20%28United%20States%29">University of the Pacific</a> in <a href="Stockton%2C%20California">Stockton, California</a> where he was a professor and later made chair of the art department. In 1983 he and his family moved to <a href="Atlanta%2C%20Georgia">Atlanta, Georgia</a> and he took a position as a professor and director of the art program at <a href="Georgia%20State%20University">Georgia State University</a>, where he taught until his retirement in 2000. He is currently represented by Mason Fine Art in <a href="Atlanta%2C%20Georgia">Atlanta, Georgia</a>.
Artwork.
In 2016, for his 80th birthday, his daughter <a href="Kara%20Walker">Kara</a> collaborated with Sikkema Jenkins, her representing gallery, for a solo exhibition for her father displaying works from over 50 years. “There’s a daughterly intention to understand connections that I lived around and reacted against,” she told the New York Times. The exhibition featured 38 works from Larry Walker's career, depicting the duress endured by human bodies and landscapes over time. His works are a part of the collections of the <a href="High%20Museum%20of%20Art">High Museum of Art</a>, the <a href="Studio%20Museum%20in%20Harlem">Studio Museum in Harlem</a>, the <a href="Philadelphia%20Museum%20of%20Art">Philadelphia Museum of Art</a>, and the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20County%20Museum%20of%20Art">Los Angeles County Museum of Art</a>. Walker also has works that are in the <a href="Museum%20of%20Contemporary%20Art%20of%20Georgia">Museum of Contemporary Art of Georgia</a>'s permanent collection where he held a two-part retrospective exhibition in 2018. Walker's work is also included in the 2020 State of the Art exhibition with <a href="Crystal%20Bridges%20Museum%20of%20American%20Art">Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art</a> as well as a solo exhibition with the <a href="Marietta/Cobb%20Museum%20of%20Art">Marietta/Cobb Museum of Art</a> in September 2020.
Personal life.
Walker has been married to his wife, Gwen, since 1958. They have three children; Dana, Larry Jr., and <a href="Kara%20Walker">Kara</a>. He currently lives and works from his home studio in <a href="Stonecrest%2C%20Georgia">Stonecrest, Georgia</a>.
